meta_data.title: Three Reasons Christians Doing Good During Plagues Made a Huge Difference
meta_data.subtitle: Galatians 6:10 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Hey, my friends, it's Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. And if this is your first time ever here, first, welcome. Every episode is a great episode to jump in. And I'm sure it's intimidating because there's a huge back catalog and you probably noticed to that you saw a small little scroll bar was over in the side of the app or window or whatever you're looking at this in. And you were thinking, wow, I'm late to the party. This is probably going to feel weird. Are you kidding me? Stop. It's the kind of party where you walk in and we just make our circle a little bigger and you're in. It's not like something you got to do to earn your stripes or something if you want to be here, you're here. So welcome. Thank you for jumping in. Today's a great day to jump in on the podcast because you're getting the last little bit of the good stuff of season five of this podcast where we're working on the book of Galatians and you're here just in time to get the feel for things before we pivot to season six, which is going to be on the book of Feileman. All of that said, today's going to be a weird episode. We don't normally do things like what we're doing today. Normally, we pick a book of the Bible and then we work through it over whatever period of time it takes to work through it. Then how do we decide what to talk about? Well, it's whatever is in that book of the Bible, whatever's next. We talk about that even if it makes me feel weird or I don't know exactly what to do with it. That's what it is. How do I mentally prepare to have these discussions? Well, by liking the Bible and being interested in what it says and reading what is in there and then following wherever the curiosity takes us as we look at it. So sometimes we linger for a very long time on just a few words or a couple verses. Sometimes maybe it seems like we go pretty quick. I don't know, maybe it never actually feels like that. Whatever the case, we have been lingering again on this one little verse that raises, I think, a very obvious question here in Galatians six and verse 10. Throughout most of the first five chapters, Paul has been dealing with a big theological question. If you want, you can go and start from the beginning of this season on Galatians if you want to. If not, you can just stay right here. But what you're going to find over the course of this season is that Paul is dealing with a theological crisis, some confusion that happened in this fledgling network of churches in Galatia, which is in modern day Turkey. But here in the last chapter and a half of the book, he's tackling very practical things. What should the Christians do now that the theology question has pretty much been spoken to? What we've talked a lot about what not to do. So now what do we do? And the answer is walk by the spirit. Be in step with the spirit. The Holy Spirit, like God in their midst. And there's been a lot of practical stuff as a result of that. And most of the practical stuff that we've read about has been pretty easy. We just read it and we're like, wait, that makes sense. Okay. Yep, that's good. That makes sense. Christians should do that. Okay, cool. Other stuff is stepped on toes a little bit more, but it says what it says. And I think Paul's right, even if he comes at it pretty assertively here, but this last one we've lingered on because Paul is saying something that's a little bit counterintuitive to modern sensibilities. He says, therefore, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all people. Everybody would agree with that. That's good. You should do good to everybody. I mean, come on. Even if you're not a Christian, I would hope that people would be like, oh, we should do good to other people, but especially for Christians in light of what God has done for Christian in light of the presence of the Holy Spirit and the values of the kingdom of God and all of that. Obviously you got to give away what you got. And what we've got is a whole bunch of good stuff. So we should give it away. But then he rounds it out like this. And he's going back to the beginning. Therefore, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all people, especially to those who belong to the family of believers. This is going to be a weird episode because I want to go and look at a, hmm, let's call it an accessible academic book that was written a few years ago by a scholar named Rodney Stark. I've mentioned this book. I've mentioned this. I say a few years ago, it was written in 1997. Dang. OK, so it was written like 30 years ago by this scholar named Rodney Stark who I think when he was writing this, I'm not sure he was coming from a perspective of belief. Maybe he was. I don't know. He was a guy who studied religion a whole bunch and wrote about things like this. But in this book called The Rise of Christianity, How the Obscure Marginal Jesus Movement Became the Dominant Religious Force in the Western World in a few centuries. In this book, he makes a bunch of jarringly pragmatic arguments as to why Christianity caught on and a whole bunch of other religions just came and went and didn't catch on. And I remember so distinctly the first time I read this book, it was first seminary class. I remember getting to chapter four of this book, which is basically making the argument that Christians were so good to each other within the family of believers, within the family of faith, like what Paul is saying in Galatians 6, 10. Stark is making the case that Christians were so exceptionally good to each other that their communities thrived. And that made other people want to be a part of that community because the values were different and interesting. Kingdom values are contagious. But also it made the community thrive because Christians didn't run when things got hard. They served each other and showed care. They didn't flee in the face of a pandemic or a famine. They hung together and ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha ha. Did you get the accidental pun there? There's an accidental pun there. It was really not that funny because it's very dark humor. It's kind of gallows humor ha ha ha ha ha ha. That was another accidental pun because the gallows humor thing I said was a pun about they all hung together, which was a pun about them enduring suffering together because at times there were persecutions. And Christians generally speaking, they just stood up to it and they took it and they did so very publicly giving up their lives. So I just want to introduce you to this chapter four that was so shocking and jarring to me because of how not spiritual the language in it was when I first encountered this book. And at first I was offended by this chapter to tell you the truth. I was like, well, no, the reason that Christianity caught on was because of miracles and the Holy Spirit. And I don't think Stark is arguing against that. I think he's saying that, like, look, if you want to believe that it's miraculous that this community embraced this approach, this value on doing good to all, but especially doing good within the family of believers, fine. Then, you know, Stark would say, cool, fine. Well, believe that that was miraculous then in this book, I'm not going to make a case one way or the other as to why they became this way. But this is who they were and here's why it worked. Chapter four, epidemics, networks and conversion. No, I'm not going to read the whole thing to you, but I am going to summarize it. He starts by talking about a moment in the 160s AD during the reign of Marcus Aurelius. Christianity was firmly established by this point, but far from being the dominant religion of the Roman world that it came to be by the mid-fourth century, the mid-300s. And so during this time, one of a series of, about five good emperors of Rome was ruling. Somebody you've probably heard of, Marcus Aurelius. He wrote philosophy books. I think he's the guy who gets pillow suffocated at the beginning of Gladiator. Haven't seen that movie in a while, I think that's right. And so at any rate, there's this horrible plague that runs through the Roman Empire and it turns to the whole thing on its head. And in a lot of ways, it's sort of the beginning of the end of a good era in the history of Rome. This thing, yeah, it just makes everything topsy-turvy. I don't know, I mean, if you're alive right now within ballpark of when I'm recording this, you remember a much more gentle plague that turned the world on its head completely. But this one was nasty. I mean, apparently a lot of medical historians think this might have been smallpox, maybe the first big time outbreak of smallpox and the history of the world, something. But whatever the case, the mortality rates were huge, Rome didn't know what to do with it. The balance of power shifted between the tribes on the edges, the fringes of the Roman Empire and Rome. And people fled Romans, that is, fled the disease in the provinces when it showed up. And then Stark says, to this end, I shall develop three theses, that was a T-H-E-S-E-S. Theses, I don't know how well that comes through on this microphone. The first of which is Stark saying, there was an order to thinking, there was an order to the world before this Marcus Aurelius era plague. Then this happened and it shook everybody up. And now they, just the common sensibilities were that the old ways have been found wanting. There was an uncertainty and instability. The second point that he argues in this book is born out of an Easter letter by Dionysia, a bishop of Alexandria. And I'll just read what Stark says about this second argument he's making. Christian values of love and charity had, from the beginning, been translated into norms of social service and community solidarity. When disasters struck, the Christians were better able to cope. And this resulted in substantially higher rates of survival. That part was in italics. The part that I said in italics, that was in italics. This meant that in the aftermath of each epidemic, and there were more than the one we're looking at here, Christians made up a larger and larger percentage of the population, even without any new converts. Moreover, their noticeably better survival rate would have seemed like a miracle to Christians and pagans alike. And this ought to have influenced conversion. There, you can see why Kidney reading this book was like, ah, these doubting miracles. And I've never really thought of the world outside of my kid faith that I'm still trying to figure out what to do with. And so I'm maybe this guy and I are enemies. Now adult me looks at that and I'm like, dang, this is somebody applying tremendous skepticism to Christian assertions and yet coming to the same conclusions that a Christian would come to. Call it a miracle. Don't call it a miracle as a Christian. I would say at the bare minimum, the miracle is that the dead, dry bones, the flesh were given life by the work of Christ, by the breath of life, the breath of God animated by the Holy Spirit. There's, that's a miracle. Every time somebody goes from dead in their sins to alive in Christ, that is a miracle. But, you know, so there needn't be any breaking of the laws of time and space beyond that to, I mean, whatever, I don't know, give artificially, miraculously drive out an infection or whatever, for me to be comfortable saying, this is miraculous, this is the miraculous work of God. But I think what Stark is talking about here is basically what I just said. He's saying that people were transformed. He might say that it was because of social religious Christian things. I would say it's a miracle of God. But he would say Christians were transformed. They behaved differently when subjected to the pressures of plague. And as a result, people looked at it after the fact and credited it to God. Maybe breaking the laws of time and space, maybe the same way I would credit it, maybe a mix of both, maybe who could say. But whatever the case, Christians survived this at a higher rate and at least a percentage of society gave credit to God. That right there is the heart of his argument. The third point that he makes the third part of his thesis here that relates to the passage we're looking at in Galatian 6 is one that sounds very harsh, very cold and very clinical. But I think he goes on in this chapter to make a pretty good case for it. And that is that when there's so much mortality when the unions of family and economic connection and communities are so damaged as they were by these series of plagues, there's going to be a new openness to new ideas and that the most stable thing in society coming off of such a calamity is likely to win out and Christianity was far and away the most stable thing in the eyes of people as evidenced by the fact that so many people converted and as evidenced by the fact that between about 200 AD and into about 350 AD, Christianity just became more and more mainstream and paganism got pushed to the margins. Okay, I'm not done with this because I actually think it's really interesting to see the research stark is done to kind of flesh out what did it look like in the ancient world when Christians took this teaching of Paul seriously, took this teaching that says, do kingdom values have fruits of the spirit and make sure that that goodness is applied to everyone, do good to everyone, but especially to those who belong to the family of faith. I'm going to look a little bit more at what this researcher Rodney Stark came up with in terms of what that looked like in the ancient world when Christians who were closer to the moment this text we've been looking at was written when they actually got pressure applied to them and had to live this thing out. That was a lot and yet there will be a lot more tomorrow. Thanks for hanging out with me. I'm Matt, this is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.
